definition.def: XQuery support is progressing fast: I have put up a few XQuery examples to demonstrate some of the new features available in the current development version. XQuery support is still far from being complete, but you can already do a lot of fascinating things.

0.9.2 is out! This is the first official release with support for XUpdate. Also, much effort has been invested to ensure that East Asian character encodings are correctly processed by the database as well as the query engine. Further changes include: important missing parts of the XPath spec have been implemented, more synchronization and database corruption bugs have been fixed and interfaces improved.

0.9.1 released! This is mainly a maintenance release, fixing many bugs found in 0.9, including eof exceptions, out-of-memory errors, and corrupted database files. It also contains further performance optimizations with respect to indexing and querying speed. New features include the highlighting of search terms in query results, simpler database startup, access to index information, new Cocoon examples, and an IzPack-based installer. For a complete list of changes see changes.xml.

section.title: Overview
section.p: eXist is an Open Source native XML database featuring efficient, index-based XPath query processing, extensions for keyword search, XUpdate support and tight integration with existing XML development tools. The database is lightweight, completely written in Java and may be easily deployed in a number of ways, running either as a stand-alone server process, inside a servlet-engine or directly embedded into an application.

Depending on how the database engine has been deployed, eXist offers several interfaces to application developers, including HTTP, XML-RPC, SOAP and WebDAV. Java developers should have a look at the XML:DB API, which provides a common interface to access XML database services.
eXist integrates well with Apache's Cocoon, allowing developers to create complex web applications entirely based on XML and related technologies.
For more information on eXist's features read the feature overview.

section.title: Download
section.p: eXist is released to the public under the terms of the GNU LGPL license.

eXist may be downloaded either as a package containing the complete distribution or as a web application archive (war-file). Download the war-file if you want to install eXist into an existing servlet-engine or write your own web application. To get started, we suggest downloading the installer or the zip package. Both contain a ready-to-run webserver (Jetty).

The distribution includes source code and all required third party libraries. Java version 1.4 or above is needed. The distribution has been tested on Linux, Solaris and Windows 2000/ME with Suns JDK 1.4 and IBM JDK 1.4. If you experience any problems on other operating systems, please send me a bug report.
The current version is 0.9.2. For instructions on starting eXist, read the Quick Start Guide.

Due to the created indexes, files stored in eXist occupy about 1.2 to 2 times the size of the raw XML source. Highly structured XML files require more space than simple structured documents.
Max. number of documents in the database:
231 documents.
Max. size per document:

Depends on the structure of the document: eXist uses unique object identifiers of type long for every XML node. A document may thus have 263 - x single XML-nodes per document, where x = 0 for an ideally well-balanced document tree. To keep x small, eXist does not balance the tree as a whole, but recomputes the ideal tree structure for every single level of the tree's node hierarchy. Thus, the long identifiers are normally more than sufficient to index large documents, because only a few identifiers are wasted for the balancing.
However, there are some documents with a very irregular structure, which cannot be mapped into the internal identifer scheme. Such documents have to be split into smaller, logical parts.

listitem.p: Apart from the fulltext index, it should be possible to define additional indexes based on type.
An existing XML schema could be used to control the indexing process. Currently, it is only possible to exclude or include selected nodes from the fulltext index.
The XPath implementation still needs some work to be done. A new implementation is on its way.

I would like to enhance the pre- and postprocessing features of eXist, probably by using concepts similar to Cocoon. Each collection could have a collection configuration document, which defines how to process documents.
